title: BibTeX and CFF
text: BibTeX well-known format storing references created Oren Patashnik Leslie Lamport back 1985. BibTeX can reused software, LaTeX, add references scholarly works. example structure BibTeX entry : case, entry (identified einstein1921) refers book. entry can used document include references . R (R Core Team 2021), can replicate structure using bibentry() toBibtex() functions: final results entry text string coerced as1: Einstein (1920). Relativity: Special General Theory. Henry Holt Company, London, United Kingdom. ISBN 9781587340925. Additionally, cffr package (Hernangómez 2021) incorporates following capabilities can used read transform BibTeX format different formats: cff_read_bib() reads *.bib files. cff_read_bib_text() can read BibTeX entries already stored variable. S3 method toBibtex.cff() converts cff objects Bibtex objects (see utils::tpBibtex()).
code: @book{einstein1921,     title        = {Relativity: The Special and the General Theory},     author       = {Einstein, A.},     year         = 1920,     publisher    = {Henry Holt and Company},     address      = {London, United Kingdom},     isbn         = 9781587340925 } entry <- bibentry("book",   key = "einstein1921",   title = "Relativity: The Special and the General Theory",   author = person("A.", "Einstein"),   year = 1920,   publisher = "Henry Holt and Company",   address = "London, United Kingdom",   isbn = 9781587340925, )  toBibtex(entry) #> @Book{einstein1921, #>   title = {Relativity: The Special and the General Theory}, #>   author = {A. Einstein}, #>   year = {1920}, #>   publisher = {Henry Holt and Company}, #>   address = {London, United Kingdom}, #>   isbn = {9781587340925}, #> } string <- "@book{einstein1921,     title        = {Relativity: The Special and the General Theory},     author       = {Einstein, A.},     year         = 1920,     publisher    = {Henry Holt and Company},     address      = {London, United Kingdom},     isbn         = 9781587340925}"  # To cff library(cffr) cff_format <- cff_read_bib_text(string)  cff_format #> - type: book #>   title: 'Relativity: The Special and the General Theory' #>   authors: #>   - family-names: Einstein #>     given-names: A. #>   year: '1920' #>   publisher: #>     name: Henry Holt and Company #>     address: London, United Kingdom #>   isbn: '9781587340925'  # To BibTeX with S3 method toBibtex(cff_format) #> @Book{einstein:1920, #>   title = {Relativity: The Special and the General Theory}, #>   author = {A. Einstein}, #>   year = {1920}, #>   publisher = {Henry Holt and Company}, #>   address = {London, United Kingdom}, #>   isbn = {9781587340925}, #> }

title: BibTeX and CFF
text: Patashnik (1988) provides comprehensive explanation BibTeX formats. Let’s distinguish Entries Fields.

title: BibTeX and CFF
text: entry type defines different type work. 14 entry types defined BibTeX : @article: article journal magazine. @book: book explicit publisher. @booklet: work printed bound, without named publisher sponsoring institution. @conference: Equivalent @inproceedings, included Scribe compatibility. @inbook: part book, may chapter (section) /range pages. @incollection: part book title. @inproceedings: article conference proceedings. @manual: Technical documentation. @mastersthesis: Master’s thesis. @misc: Use type nothing else fits. @phdthesis: PhD thesis. @proceedings: proceedings conference. @techreport: report published school institution, usually numbered within series. @unpublished: document author title, formally published. implementations similar BibTeX, BibLaTeX (Kime, Wemheuer, Lehman 2023), expand definitions entries include types online resources, software, datasets. BibTeX, entries reclassified @misc. R, bibentry() base function implement @conference. However, can use @inproceedings, instead given definition identical.

title: BibTeX and CFF
text: Similar Entries, Patashnik (1988) also provides definitions possible standard BibTeX fields. entry must include certain required fields, can also include additional fields might ignored raw implementation BibTeX. Let’s explore fields: address: Typically represents address publisher another institution. case @conference, @inproceedings @proceedings field indicates conference held. annote: annotation. Although used standard bibliography styles, may relevant producing annotated bibliographies. author: Contains name(s) author(s), following format described LaTeX book (Lamport 1986). booktitle: Refers title book, part cited. @book entries, use title field instead. chapter: Indicates chapter (section) number. crossref: Refers database key entry cross-referenced. edition: Specifies edition @book, e.g., "Second". ordinal first letter capitalized; standard styles convert lowercase necessary. editor: Contains name(s) editor(s), following conventions LaTeX book (Lamport 1986). also author field, editor field specifies editor book collection reference appears. howpublished: Describes something unusual published. first word capitalized. institution: Represents sponsoring institution technical report. journal: Refers name journal. key: Used alphabetizing, cross-referencing, creating label author information missing. month: Indicates month work published , unpublished work, written. Use standard three-letter abbreviation (e.g., jan, feb, mar) described Appendix B.1.3 LaTeX book (Lamport 1986). note: Provides additional information can assist reader. first word capitalized. number: Represents number journal, magazine, technical report, work series. issue journal magazine usually identified volume number. Organizations issuing technical reports often assign numbers, sometimes books given numbers within named series. organization: Refers organization sponsors @conference publishes manual. pages: Specifies one page numbers range numbers (e.g., 42--111 7,41,73--97 43+). publisher: Indicates publisher’s name. school: Provides name school thesis written. series: Specifies name series set books. citing entire book, title field gives title, optional series field provides name series multi-volume set book published. title: Represents work’s title. type: Describes type technical report (e.g., “Research Note”). volume: Refers volume journal multi-volume book. year: Indicates year publication , unpublished work, year written. Generally, consist four numerals (e.g., 1984). case Entries, implementations BibLaTeX recognize additional fields. BibTeX, exists strict relationship Entries Fields. Depending type entry, certain fields required, others optional even ignored. following table summarizes relationship Entries Fields BibTeX. Required fields flagged x, optional fields flagged o. detailed information, refer Patashnik (1988). BibTeX, required fields entry (cont) BibTeX, required fields entry can seen subset fields necessary entry. instance, title, year, author either required optional almost every entry, whereas crossref, annote, key never mandatory.

title: BibTeX and CFF
text: Citation File Format (CFF) (Druskat et al. 2021) consists plain text files containing human- machine-readable citation information software datasets. Within CFF, two important keys: preferred-citation references, play crucial role citing referring related works: preferred-citation: Refers another work cited instead software dataset . references: Includes reference(s) creative works related software dataset. Similar list references scholarly paper, references may encompass papers describing abstract concepts software algorithms implemented software version. two keys expected definition.reference objects, defined Guide Citation File Format schema version 1.2.0, may contain following keys: Valid keys [CFF]{underline} definition-reference objects keys equivalent BibTeX fields, exception key type. CFF, key defines type work2, making analogous BibTeX entries.

what: Appendix A: @inbook in BibTeX and BibLaTeX
title: BibTeX and CFF
text: definition @inbook @incollection BibTeX (Patashnik 1988) follows: @inbook: part book, may chapter (section) /range pages. Required fields: author editor, title, chapter /pages, publisher, year (…) @incollection: part book title. Required fields: author, title, booktitle, publisher, year (…) Whereas BibLaTeX (Kime, Wemheuer, Lehman 2023) specifies: @inbook: part book forms self-contained unit title. Note profile entry type different standard BibTeX, see § 2.3.1. Required fields: author, title, booktitle, year/date (…). considering required fields, important difference booktitle requirement BibLaTeX. Notably, BibTeX @incollection requires also field. Moreover, BibTeX @incollection BibLaTeX @inbook emphasize reference “part book (…) title”. document, proposed crosswalk ensures full compatibility BibTeX. Hence, propose consider BibLaTeX @inbook entry equivalent BibTeX @incollection, given congruence definitions field requirements. Examples BibTeX entry CFF entry CFF BibTeX

title: Manipulating Citations with cffr
text: Citation File Format (CFF) (Druskat et al. 2021) (v1.2.0) plain text files human- machine-readable citation information software (data sets). Code developers can include repositories let others know correctly cite software. format becoming popular within software citation ecosystem. Recently GitHub, Zenodo Zotero included full support citation format (Druskat 2021). GitHub support special interest:  — Nat Friedman (@natfriedman) July 27, 2021 See Customize repository/CITATION files info.

what: Creating a CITATION.cff file for my R package
title: Manipulating Citations with cffr
text: cffr creating CITATION.cff file quite straightforward. just need run cff_write(): hood, cff_write() performs following tasks: extracts metadata using cff_create(). Optionally modifies cff_modify(). Writes CITATION.cff file. Validates result using cff_validate(). Congratulations! Now full CITATION.cff file R package.
code: library(cffr)  cff_write()  # You are done!

title: Manipulating Citations with cffr
text: can easily customize cff object (custom class cffr) using coercion system provided package, well making use keys parameter. create cff object using cff() (example purposes ) add modify contents .

title: Manipulating Citations with cffr
text: valid keys Citation File Format schema version 1.2.0 can displayed cff_schema_keys(): case, going add url, version repository. also overwrite title key. just need add parameters cff_modify():
code: newobject <- cff()  newobject #> cff-version: 1.2.0 #> message: If you use this software, please cite it using these metadata. #> title: My Research Software #> authors: #> - family-names: Doe #>   given-names: John cff_schema_keys() #>  [1] "cff-version"         "message"             "type"                #>  [4] "license"             "title"               "version"             #>  [7] "doi"                 "abstract"            "authors"             #> [10] "preferred-citation"  "repository"          "repository-artifact" #> [13] "repository-code"     "url"                 "date-released"       #> [16] "contact"             "keywords"            "references"          #> [19] "commit"              "identifiers"         "license-url" modobject <- cff_modify(newobject,   url = "https://ropensci.org/",   version = "0.0.1",   repository = "https://github.com/ropensci/cffr",   # If the field is already present, it would be overridden   title = "Modifying a 'cff' object" )  modobject #> cff-version: 1.2.0 #> message: If you use this software, please cite it using these metadata. #> title: Modifying a 'cff' object #> authors: #> - family-names: Doe #>   given-names: John #> url: https://ropensci.org/ #> version: 0.0.1 #> repository: https://github.com/ropensci/cffr  # Validate against the schema  cff_validate(modobject) #> ══ Validating cff ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ #> ✔ Congratulations! This <cff> is valid

title: Manipulating Citations with cffr
text: cffr provides two functions convert person bibentry objects (see ?person ?bibentry) according Citation File Format schema. Following previous example, going add new author first. , need first extract current author package append coerced person: Now, may want add references data. following example, add two references, one created bibentry() another citation(): Now process similar example person: just modify cff object:
code: # Valid person keys  cff_schema_definitions_person() #>  [1] "address"       "affiliation"   "alias"         "city"          #>  [5] "country"       "email"         "family-names"  "fax"           #>  [9] "given-names"   "name-particle" "name-suffix"   "orcid"         #> [13] "post-code"     "region"        "tel"           "website"  # Create the person  chiquito <- person("Gregorio",   "Sánchez Fernández",   email = "fake@email2.com",   comment = c(     alias = "Chiquito de la Calzada",     city = "Malaga",     country = "ES",     ORCID = "0000-0000-0000-0001"   ) )  chiquito #> [1] "Gregorio Sánchez Fernández <fake@email2.com> (Chiquito de la Calzada, Malaga, ES, <https://orcid.org/0000-0000-0000-0001>)"  # To cff chiquito_cff <- as_cff_person(chiquito) chiquito_cff #> - family-names: Sánchez Fernández #>   given-names: Gregorio #>   email: fake@email2.com #>   alias: Chiquito de la Calzada #>   city: Malaga #>   country: ES #>   orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0000-0000-0001   # Append to previous authors  newauthors <- c(modobject$authors, chiquito_cff) newauthors #> - family-names: Doe #>   given-names: John #> - family-names: Sánchez Fernández #>   given-names: Gregorio #>   email: fake@email2.com #>   alias: Chiquito de la Calzada #>   city: Malaga #>   country: ES #>   orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0000-0000-0001  newauthorobject <- cff_modify(modobject, authors = newauthors)  newauthorobject #> cff-version: 1.2.0 #> message: If you use this software, please cite it using these metadata. #> title: Modifying a 'cff' object #> authors: #> - family-names: Doe #>   given-names: John #> - family-names: Sánchez Fernández #>   given-names: Gregorio #>   email: fake@email2.com #>   alias: Chiquito de la Calzada #>   city: Malaga #>   country: ES #>   orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0000-0000-0001 #> url: https://ropensci.org/ #> version: 0.0.1 #> repository: https://github.com/ropensci/cffr  cff_validate(newauthorobject) #> ══ Validating cff ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ #> ✔ Congratulations! This <cff> is valid # Valid reference keys  cff_schema_definitions_refs() #>  [1] "abbreviation"        "abstract"            "authors"             #>  [4] "collection-doi"      "collection-title"    "collection-type"     #>  [7] "commit"              "conference"          "contact"             #> [10] "copyright"           "data-type"           "database-provider"   #> [13] "database"            "date-accessed"       "date-downloaded"     #> [16] "date-published"      "date-released"       "department"          #> [19] "doi"                 "edition"             "editors"             #> [22] "editors-series"      "end"                 "entry"               #> [25] "filename"            "format"              "identifiers"         #> [28] "institution"         "isbn"                "issn"                #> [31] "issue"               "issue-date"          "issue-title"         #> [34] "journal"             "keywords"            "languages"           #> [37] "license"             "license-url"         "loc-end"             #> [40] "loc-start"           "location"            "medium"              #> [43] "month"               "nihmsid"             "notes"               #> [46] "number"              "number-volumes"      "pages"               #> [49] "patent-states"       "pmcid"               "publisher"           #> [52] "recipients"          "repository"          "repository-artifact" #> [55] "repository-code"     "scope"               "section"             #> [58] "senders"             "start"               "status"              #> [61] "term"                "thesis-type"         "title"               #> [64] "translators"         "type"                "url"                 #> [67] "version"             "volume"              "volume-title"        #> [70] "year"                "year-original"  # Auto coercion from another R package base_r <- citation("base")  bib <- bibentry("Book",   title = "This is a book",   author = "Lisa Lee",   year = 1980,   publisher = "McGraw Hill",   volume = 2 )  refs <- c(base_r, bib)  refs #> R Core Team (2023). _R: A Language and Environment for Statistical #> Computing_. R Foundation for Statistical Computing, Vienna, Austria. #> <https://www.R-project.org/>. #>  #> Lee L (1980). _This is a book_, volume 2. McGraw Hill.  # Now to cff  refs_cff <- as_cff(refs)  refs_cff #> - type: manual #>   title: 'R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing' #>   authors: #>   - name: R Core Team #>   institution: #>     name: R Foundation for Statistical Computing #>     address: Vienna, Austria #>   year: '2023' #>   url: https://www.R-project.org/ #> - type: book #>   title: This is a book #>   authors: #>   - family-names: Lee #>     given-names: Lisa #>   year: '1980' #>   publisher: #>     name: McGraw Hill #>   volume: '2' finalobject <- cff_modify(newauthorobject, references = refs_cff)  finalobject #> cff-version: 1.2.0 #> message: If you use this software, please cite it using these metadata. #> title: Modifying a 'cff' object #> authors: #> - family-names: Doe #>   given-names: John #> - family-names: Sánchez Fernández #>   given-names: Gregorio #>   email: fake@email2.com #>   alias: Chiquito de la Calzada #>   city: Malaga #>   country: ES #>   orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0000-0000-0001 #> url: https://ropensci.org/ #> version: 0.0.1 #> repository: https://github.com/ropensci/cffr #> references: #> - type: manual #>   title: 'R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing' #>   authors: #>   - name: R Core Team #>   institution: #>     name: R Foundation for Statistical Computing #>     address: Vienna, Austria #>   year: '2023' #>   url: https://www.R-project.org/ #> - type: book #>   title: This is a book #>   authors: #>   - family-names: Lee #>     given-names: Lisa #>   year: '1980' #>   publisher: #>     name: McGraw Hill #>   volume: '2'  cff_validate(finalobject) #> ══ Validating cff ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ #> ✔ Congratulations! text: results can written cff_write(): finally can read created CITATION.cff file using cff_read(): Note cff_write() also keys param, workflow can simplified :
code: # For example tmp <- tempfile(fileext = ".cff")  see_res <- cff_write(finalobject, outfile = tmp) #> ✔ /tmp/RtmpFQE5fI/file8b52410904d.cff generated #> ══ Validating cff ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ #> ✔ Congratulations! /tmp/RtmpFQE5fI/file8b52410904d.cff is valid  cat(readLines(tmp), sep = "\n") #> # -------------------------------------------- #> # CITATION file created with {cffr} R package #> # See also: https://docs.ropensci.org/cffr/ #> # -------------------------------------------- #>   #> cff-version: 1.2.0 #> message: If you use this software, please cite it using these metadata. #> title: Modifying a 'cff' object #> version: 0.0.1 #> authors: #> - family-names: Doe #>   given-names: John #> - family-names: Sánchez Fernández #>   given-names: Gregorio #>   email: fake@email2.com #>   alias: Chiquito de la Calzada #>   city: Malaga #>   country: ES #>   orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0000-0000-0001 #> repository: https://github.com/ropensci/cffr #> url: https://ropensci.org/ #> references: #> - title: From R to CFF
text: summarize fields cffr can coerce original source information one . details key presented next section document. assessment fields based Guide Citation File Format schema version 1.2.0 (Druskat et al. 2021).

title: From R to CFF
text: key extracted "Description" field DESCRIPTION file. Back summary.
code: library(cffr)  # Create cffr for yaml  cff_obj <- cff_create("rmarkdown")  # Get DESCRIPTION of rmarkdown to check  pkg <- desc::desc(file.path(find.package("rmarkdown"), "DESCRIPTION"))  cat(cff_obj$abstract) #> Convert R Markdown documents into a variety of formats.  cat(pkg$get("Description")) #> Convert R Markdown documents into a variety of formats.

title: From R to CFF
text: key coerced "Authors" "Authors@R" field DESCRIPTION file. default persons role "aut" "cre" considered, however can modified via authors_roles parameter. Back summary.
code: # An example DESCRIPTION path <- system.file("examples/DESCRIPTION_many_persons", package = "cffr") pkg <- desc::desc(path)  # See persons listed pkg$get_authors() #> [1] "Diego Hernangómez <fake@gmail.com> [aut, cre] (<https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8457-4658>, error, error)" #> [2] "Joe Doe <I am a wrong email> [aut] (This One, ES, error)"                                              #> [3] "Pepe Doe <fake@gmail.com> [aut] (error)"                                                               #> [4] "I am an entity [cre] (2020-01-01, error)"                                                              #> [5] "ERROR entity [cph] (for the administrative boundaries.)"                                               #> [6] "ERROR person [cph] (<https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2042-7063>, for the gisco_countrycode dataset.)"   # Default behaviour, use authors and creators (maintainers) cff_obj <- cff_create(path) cff_obj$authors #> - family-names: Hernangómez #>   given-names: Diego #>   email: fake@gmail.com #>   orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8457-4658 #> - family-names: Doe #>   given-names: Joe #>   affiliation: This One #>   country: ES #> - family-names: Doe #>   given-names: Pepe #>   email: fake@gmail.com #> - name: I am an entity #>   date-end: '2020-01-01'   # Use now Copyright holders and maintainers cff_obj_alt <- cff_create(path, authors_roles = c("cre", "cph")) cff_obj_alt$authors #> - family-names: Hernangómez #>   given-names: Diego #>   email: fake@gmail.com #>   orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8457-4658 #> - name: I am an entity #>   date-end: '2020-01-01' #> - name: ERROR entity #> - family-names: person #>   given-names: ERROR #>   orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0003-2042-7063

title: From R to CFF
text: key extracted DESCRIPTION file following logic: "Date" field , present, "Date/Publication". present packages built CRAN Bioconductor. , present, "Packaged", present packages built r-universe. Back summary.

title: From R to CFF
text: key includes possible identifiers package: DESCRIPTION field, includes urls included url repository-code. CITATION file, includes dois included doi identifiers () included "identifiers" key preferred-citation. Back summary.
code: file <- system.file("examples/DESCRIPTION_many_urls", package = "cffr")  pkg <- desc::desc(file)  cat(pkg$get_urls()) #> https://github.com/test/package https://test.github.io/package/ https://r-forge.r-project.org/projects/test/ http://google.ru https://gitlab.com/r-packages/behaviorchange  cat(cff_create(file)$url) #> https://test.github.io/package/  cat(cff_create(file)$`repository-code`) #> https://github.com/test/package  cff_create(file)$identifiers #> - type: url #>   value: https://r-forge.r-project.org/projects/test/ #> - type: url #>   value: http://google.ru #> - type: url #>   value: https://gitlab.com/r-packages/behaviorchange

title: From R to CFF
text: key extracted "Repository" field DESCRIPTION file. Usually, field auto-populated package hosted repo (like CRAN r-universe). packages without field DESCRIPTION (typical case -development package), cffr try search package default repositories specified options("repos"). case Bioconductor packages, identified “biocViews” present DESCRIPTION file. cffr detects package available CRAN, return canonical url form package (.e. https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=jsonlite). Back summary.
code: # Installed package  inst <- cff_create("jsonlite")  cat(inst$repository) #> https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=jsonlite  # Demo file downloaded from the r-universe  runiv <- system.file("examples/DESCRIPTION_r_universe", package = "cffr") runiv_cff <- cff_create(runiv)  cat(runiv_cff$repository) #> https://ropensci.r-universe.dev  desc::desc(runiv)$get("Repository") #>                        Repository  #> "https://ropensci.r-universe.dev"  # For in development package  norepo <- system.file("examples/DESCRIPTION_basic", package = "cffr")  # No repo norepo_cff <- cff_create(norepo)  cat(norepo_cff[["repository"]])  # Change the name to a known package on CRAN: ggplot2  tmp <- tempfile("DESCRIPTION") file.copy(norepo, tmp) #> [1] TRUE   # Change name desc::desc_set("Package", "ggplot2", file = tmp) #> Type: Package #> Package: ggplot2 #> Title: A Basic Description #> Version: 0.1.6 #> Authors@R (parsed): #>     * Marc Basic <marcbasic@gmail.com> [aut, cre, cph] #> Description: A very basic description. Should parse without #>     problems. #> License: GPL-3 #> URL: https://github.com/basic/package, #>     https://basic.github.io/package #> BugReports: https://github.com/basic/package/issues #> Encoding: UTF-8 #> LazyData: true #> RoxygenNote: 6.0.1.9000  cat(cff_create(tmp)[["repository"]]) #> https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=ggplot2

This package provides utilities to #>     generate, parse, and modify 'codemeta.json' files automatically for R #>     packages, as well as tools and examples for working with #>     'codemeta.json' 'JSON-LD' more generally. #> License: GPL-3 #> URL: https://gitlab.com/ninijay/methoden, #>     https://ropensci.github.io/codemetar #> BugReports: https://gitlab.com/ninijay/methoden/-/issues #> Depends: #>     R (>= 3.0.0) #> Imports: #>     crul, #>     desc, #>     devtools, #>     gh, #>     git2r, #>     jsonld, #>     jsonlite (>= 1.3), #>     memoise, #>     methods, #>     purrr, #>     readr, #>     sessioninfo, #>     stats, #>     stringi, #>     stringr, #>     tibble, #>     usethis, #>     whisker #> Suggests: #>     covr, #>     dplyr (>= 0.7.0), #>     jsonvalidate, #>     knitr, #>     magrittr, #>     printr, #>     rmarkdown, #>     testthat, #>     xml2 #> VignetteBuilder: #>     knitr #> Encoding: UTF-8 #> LazyData: true #> RoxygenNote: 6.0.1.9000 #> X-schema.org-isPartOf: https://ropensci.org #> X-schema.org-keywords: metadata, codemeta, ropensci, citation, #>     credit, linked-data

title: cffr: Generate Citation File Format Metadata for R Packages
text: Citation File Format project (Druskat et al. 2021) defines standardized format providing software datasets citation metadata plaintext files easy read humans machines. metadata format adopted GitHub primary format built-citation support (GitHub 2021). leading archives scientific software, including Zenodo Zotero (Druskat 2021), included well support CITATION.cff files GitHub integration. cffr package provides utilities generate validate CITATION.cff files automatically R (R Core Team 2021) packages parsing DESCRIPTION file native R citation file. package also includes utilities examples parsing components persons additional citations, well several vignettes illustrate basic usage package well technical details metadata extraction process.

title: cffr: Generate Citation File Format Metadata for R Packages
text: Citation research software research project often omitted (Salmon, Chamberlain, Ram 2021) . Among many reasons software cited, one lack clear citation information package developers. main reasons citing software used research : Reproducibility: Software versions important information include research project. helps peers understand reproduce effectively results work. Including versions also crucial way recording context manuscript software changes. Developer Credit: context Free Open Source Software (FOSS), many software developers also researches. Receive credit software development shouldn’t different credit received formats, books articles. CITATION.cff files provides clear citation rules software. format easily readable humans also can parsed appropriate software. adoption GitHub format sends strong message research software something worthy citation, therefore deserves credit. cffr package allow R software developers create CITATION.cff files metadata already included package. Additionally, package also include validation tools via jsonvalidate package (FitzJohn et al. 2021), allow developers assess validity file created using latest CFF schema.json.

title: cffr | Generate Citation File Format (CFF) files for R packages
text: Citation File Format (CFF) (Druskat et al. 2021) (v1.2.0) plain text files human- machine-readable citation information software (datasets). Code developers can include repositories let others know correctly cite software. format becoming popular within software citation ecosystem. Recently GitHub, Zenodo Zotero included full support citation format (Druskat 2021). GitHub support special interest:  — Nat Friedman (@natfriedman) July 27, 2021 See Enhanced support citations GitHub (Smith 2021) info.

title: cffr | Generate Citation File Format (CFF) files for R packages
text: CodeMeta Project (Jones et al. 2017) creates concept vocabulary can used standardize exchange software metadata across repositories organizations. One many uses codemeta.json file (created following standards defined CodeMeta Project) provide citation metadata title, authors, publication year, venue (Fenner 2021). packages codemeta (Boettiger Salmon 2021a) / codemetar (Boettiger Salmon 2021b) allows generate codemeta.json files R packages metadata.

title: Coerce R objects to cff_pers_lst objects (cff persons) — as_cff_person
text: as_cff_person() recognize input converted using CFF reference definition.person definition.entity. as_cff_person() uses custom algorithm tries break name explained Section 11 "Tame BeaST" (Markey, 2007) (see also Decoret, 2007): First von Last. von Last, First. von Last, Jr, First. Mapping performed follows: First mapped CFF field given-names. von mapped CFF field name-particle. Last mapped CFF field family-names. Jr mapped CFF field name-suffix. case entities, whole character mapped name. good practice "protect" entity's names {}:   as_cff_person() try add many information possible. character string coming format.person() email ORCID retrieved well.
code: # Don't do entity <- "Elephant and Castle" as_cff_person(entity) - name: Elephant - name: Castle  # Do entity_protect <- "{Elephant and Castle}" as_cff_person(entity_protect) - name: Elephant and Castle

"Tame BeaST" B X BibTeX, Version 1.4 (October 2007). https://osl.ugr.es/CTAN/info/bibtex/tamethebeast/ttb_en.pdf. Decoret X (2007). "summary BibTex."https://maverick.inria.fr/~Xavier.Decoret/resources/xdkbibtex/bibtex_summary.html#names See Examples information.

title: Coerce R objects to cff_pers_lst objects (cff persons) — as_cff_person
code: # Create a person object a_person <- person(   given = "First", family = "Author",   role = c("aut", "cre"),   email = "first.last@example.com", comment = c(     ORCID = "0000-0001-8457-4658",     affiliation = "An affiliation"   ) )  a_person #> [1] "First Author <first.last@example.com> [aut, cre] (<https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8457-4658>, An affiliation)"  cff_person <- as_cff_person(a_person)  # Class cff_pers_lst / cff class(cff_person) #> [1] "cff_pers_lst" "cff"           # With each element with class cff_pers / cff class(cff_person[[1]]) #> [1] "cff_pers" "cff"       # Print cff_person #> - family-names: Author #>   given-names: First #>   email: first.last@example.com #>   orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8457-4658 #>   affiliation: An affiliation  # Back to person object with S3 Method as.person(cff_person) #> [1] "First Author <first.last@example.com> (<https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8457-4658>, An affiliation)"  # Coerce a string a_str <- paste0(   "Julio Iglesias <fake@email.com> ",   "(<https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8457-4658>)" ) as_cff_person(a_str) #> - family-names: Iglesias #>   given-names: Julio #>   email: fake@email.com #>   orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0001-8457-4658  # Several persons persons <- c(   person("Clark", "Kent", comment = c(affiliation = "Daily Planet")),   person("Lois", "Lane"), person("Oscorp Inc.") )  a_cff <- as_cff_person(persons)  a_cff #> - family-names: Kent #>   given-names: Clark #>   affiliation: Daily Planet #> - family-names: Lane #>   given-names: Lois #> - name: Oscorp Inc.  # Printed as Bibtex thanks to the method toBibtex(a_cff) #> [1] "Kent, Clark and Lane, Lois and {Oscorp Inc.}"  # Or as person object as.person(a_cff) #> [1] "Clark Kent (Daily Planet)" "Lois Lane"                 #> [3] "Oscorp Inc."                 # Or you can use BibTeX style as input if you prefer  x <- "Frank Sinatra and Dean Martin and Davis, Jr., Sammy and Joey Bishop"  as_cff_person(x) #> - family-names: Sinatra #>   given-names: Frank #> - family-names: Martin #>   given-names: Dean #> - family-names: Davis #>   given-names: Sammy #>   name-suffix: Jr. #> - family-names: Bishop #>   given-names: Joey  as_cff_person("Herbert von Karajan") #> - family-names: Karajan #>   given-names: Herbert #>   name-particle: von  toBibtex(as_cff_person("Herbert von Karajan")) #> [1] "von Karajan, Herbert"

title: The cff class — cff_class
text: cffr implements S3 object class cff, used represent information CITATION.cff file R. hood, cff object simply named list added additional methods, notably print as_cff().   as_cff() converts list cff also removes items (known keys CFF terminology) NULL NA.
code: a_named_list <- list(   first = "I", second = "am", third = "a", fourth = "list",   fifth = "with", sixth = "names", "none" = NULL )  # As cff a_cff_object <- as_cff(a_named_list)  class(a_cff_object) #> [1] "cff"  a_cff_object #> first: I #> second: am #> third: a #> fourth: list #> fifth: with #> sixth: names  is.list(a_cff_object) #> [1] TRUE

title: The cff class — cff_class
text: cffr implements two special sub-classes cff, aim representing two special types objects defined CFF Schema: definition.person definition.entity: CFF definition sub-lists representing persons entities. cffr sub-class cff_pers_lst implemented collect array definition.person/entity, individual person entity array sub-class cff_pers. Similarly, definition.reference definition CFF collecting references related works articles software used development main work CFF file. implemented cffr sub-class named cff_ref_lst arrays definition.reference element array sub-class named cff_ref. two sub-classes provide full valid cff objects, adapts information schema required CFF:
code: # Using the utils::person() function  ## Array two_persons <- as_cff_person(   c(     person("A", "person", comment = c(ORCID = "0000-0000-0000-0000")),     person("An entity", email = "fake@gmail.com")   ) )  two_persons #> - family-names: person #>   given-names: A #>   orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0000-0000-0000 #> - name: An entity #>   email: fake@gmail.com  class(two_persons) #> [1] "cff_pers_lst" "cff"  # Single element  two_persons[[1]] #> family-names: person #> given-names: A #> orcid: https://orcid.org/0000-0000-0000-0000  class(two_persons[[1]]) #> [1] "cff_pers" "cff"  # Array of references  cit <- c(citation(), citation("yaml"))  ref_list <- as_cff(cit)  ref_list #> - type: manual #>   title: 'R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing' #>   authors: #>   - name: R Core Team #>   institution: #>     name: R Foundation for Statistical Computing #>     address: Vienna, Austria #>   year: '2024' #>   url: https://www.R-project.org/ #> - type: manual #>   title: 'yaml: Methods to Convert R Data to YAML and Back' #>   authors: #>   - family-names: Garbett #>     given-names: Shawn P #>   - family-names: Stephens #>     given-names: Jeremy #>   - family-names: Simonov #>     given-names: Kirill #>   - family-names: Xie #>     given-names: Yihui #>   - family-names: Dong #>     given-names: Zhuoer #>   - family-names: Wickham #>     given-names: Hadley #>   - family-names: Horner #>     given-names: Jeffrey #>   - name: reikoch #>   - family-names: Beasley #>     given-names: Will #>   - family-names: O'Connor #>     given-names: Brendan #>   - family-names: Warnes #>     given-names: Gregory R. #>   - family-names: Quinn #>     given-names: Michael #>   - family-names: Kamvar #>     given-names: Zhian N. #>   year: '2023' #>   notes: R package version 2.3.8 #>   url: https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=yaml  class(ref_list) #> [1] "cff_ref_lst" "cff"  # Single element  ref_list[[1]] #> type: manual #> title: 'R: A Language and Environment for Statistical Computing' #> authors: #> - name: R Core Team #> institution: #>   name: R Foundation for Statistical Computing #>   address: Vienna, Austria #> year: '2024' #> url: https://www.R-project.org/  class(ref_list[[1]]) #> [1] "cff_ref" "cff"

title: The cff class — cff_class
text: Creating cff object ensure validity according CFF Schema:   cff_validate() gives minimal messages wrong cff (invisibly) returns result validation (TRUE/FALSE). can use cff_modify() add keys:
code: class(a_cff_object) #> [1] "cff"  cff_validate(a_cff_object) #> == Validating cff ============================================================== #> x Oops! This <cff> has the following errors: #> * cff.authors: is required #> * cff["cff-version"]: is required #> * cff.message: is required #> * cff.title: is required cff_valid <- cff_modify(a_cff_object,   authors = as_cff_person("{James and James}"),   cff_version = "1.2.0",   message = "Hi there",   title = "My title" )   # Remove invalid keys cff_valid <- as_cff(cff_valid[names(cff_valid) %in% cff_schema_keys()])  cff_valid #> authors: #> - name: James and James #> cff-version: 1.2.0 #> message: Hi there #> title: My title  cff_validate(cff_valid) #> == Validating cff ============================================================== #> v Congratulations! This <cff> is valid

title: Use a git pre-commit hook  — cff_git_hook

However, mechanism detection perfect triggered also even tried update CITATION.cff file. typically case updated DESCRIPTION inst/CITATION files changes make change CITATION.cff file (.e. including new dependencies). cases, can override check running git commit ---verify terminal. using RStudio can run also command R script selecting line sending terminal using: Windows & Linux: Ctrl+Alt+Enter. Mac: Cmd+Option+Return.

what: Read an external file as a cff object — cff_read
title: Read an external file as a cff object — cff_read
text: Read files convert cff objects. Files supported : CITATION.cff files. DESCRIPTION files. R citation files (usually located inst/CITATION). BibTeX files (extension *.bib). cff_read() try guess type file provided path. However provide series alias specific type file: cff_read_cff_citation(), uses yaml::read_yaml(). cff_read_description(), using desc::desc(). cff_read_citation() uses utils::readCitationFile(). cff_read_bib()  requires bibtex (>= 0.5.0) uses bibtex::read.bib().

title: Read an external file as a cff object — cff_read
code: cff_read(path, ...)  cff_read_cff_citation(path, ...)  cff_read_description(   path,   cff_version = "1.2.0",   gh_keywords = TRUE,   authors_roles = c("aut", "cre"),   ... )  cff_read_citation(path, meta = NULL, ...)  cff_read_bib(path, encoding = "UTF-8", ...)

title: Read an external file as a cff object — cff_read

See Details. meta list package metadata obtained utils::packageDescription() NULL (default). See Details. encoding Encoding assumed path. See readLines().

title: Validate a CITATION.cff file or a cff object — cff_validate
code: # \donttest{ # Full .cff example cff_validate(system.file("examples/CITATION_complete.cff", package = "cffr")) #> ══ Validating cff ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ #> ✔ Congratulations! /usr/local/lib/R/site-library/cffr/examples/CITATION_complete.cff is valid  # Validate a cffr object cffr <- cff_create("jsonlite") class(cffr) #> [1] "cff" cff_validate(cffr) #> ══ Validating cff ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ #> ✔ Congratulations! This <cff> is valid # }  # .cff with errors err_f <- system.file("examples/CITATION_error.cff", package = "cffr") # Can manipulate the errors as data frame res <- try(cff_validate(err_f)) #> ══ Validating cff ══════════════════════════════════════════════════════════════ #> ✖ Oops! /usr/local/lib/R/site-library/cffr/examples/CITATION_error.cff has the following errors: #> * cff: has additional properties #> * cff.authors.0: no schemas match #> * cff.doi: referenced schema does not match #> * cff.keywords.0: is the wrong type #> * cff.license: referenced schema does not match #> * cff.url: referenced schema does not match  isTRUE(res) #> [1] FALSE isFALSE(res) #> [1] TRUE  attr(res, "errors") #>            field                          message #> 1            cff        has additional properties #> 2  cff.authors.0                 no schemas match #> 3        cff.doi referenced schema does not match #> 4 cff.keywords.0                is the wrong type #> 5    cff.license referenced schema does not match #> 6        cff.url referenced schema does not match  # If a CITATION file (note that is not .cff) it throws an error try(cff_validate(system.file("CITATION", package = "cffr"))) #> Error in abort_if_not_cff(x) : `x` is not a '*.cff' file.

title: Write a CITATION.cff file — cff_write
text: x source used generating cff object. : missing value. retrieve DESCRIPTION file -development R package. existing cff object. name installed package ("jsonlite"). Path DESCRIPTION file ("./DESCRIPTION"). outfile name path CITATION.cff created. keys List additional keys add cff object. See cff_modify(). cff_version Citation File Format schema version CITATION.cff file adheres providing citation metadata. gh_keywords Logical TRUE/FALSE. package hosted GitHub, like add repo topics keywords? dependencies Logical TRUE/FALSE. like add package references CFF key? validate validate Logical TRUE/FALSE. new file validated using cff_validate()? verbose Logical TRUE/FALSE. TRUE function display informative messages. authors_roles Roles considered authors package generating CITATION.cff file. See Details. encoding name encoding assumed. Default "UTF-8", can value accepted iconv(), "ASCII//TRANSLIT".

SIAM Press, Philadelphia. ISBN #>   978111976304, <https://github.com/bueler/p4pdes>. #>  #> A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is #>  #>   @Book{bueler:2021, #>     title = {PETSc for Partial Differential Equations: Numerical Solutions in C and Python}, #>     author = {Ed Bueler}, #>     year = {2021}, #>     publisher = {SIAM Press}, #>     address = {Philadelphia}, #>     isbn = {978111976304}, #>     url = {https://github.com/bueler/p4pdes}, #>   }

code: bib <- bibentry("Misc",   title = "My title",   author = "Fran Pérez" )  my_temp_bib <- tempfile(fileext = ".bib")  cff_write_bib(bib, file = my_temp_bib) #> ℹ Writing 4 entries ... #> ✔ Results written to /tmp/RtmpMmliiN/file6111c6d5e03.bib  cat(readLines(my_temp_bib), sep = "\n") #> @Misc{, #>   title = {My title}, #>   author = {Fran Pérez}, #> }  cff_write_bib(bib, file = my_temp_bib, ascii = TRUE, append = TRUE) #> ℹ Creating a backup of /tmp/RtmpMmliiN/file6111c6d5e03.bib in /tmp/RtmpMmliiN/file6111c6d5e03.bib.bk1 #> ℹ Writing 4 entries ... #> ✔ Results written to /tmp/RtmpMmliiN/file6111c6d5e03.bib  cat(readLines(my_temp_bib), sep = "\n") #> @Misc{, #>   title = {My title}, #>   author = {Fran Pérez}, #> } #> @Misc{, #>   title = {My title}, #>   author = {Fran P{\'e}rez}, #> }

title: cffr 1.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-03-12 major release notable changes. change mainly affects non-core functions, hence natural workflow (cff_create() → cff_write() → cff_validate()) shouldn’t affected.

title: cffr 1.0.0
text: Now cffr implements new class system definitions.reference, definitions.person definitions.entity objects: List definitions.reference (e.g, references) class cff_ref_lst, cff individual elements (e.g preferred-citation member references) class cff_ref, cff. List definitions.person definitions.entity (e.g. authors, contact) class cff_pers_lst, cff individual elements (e.g publisher member authors) class cff_pers, cff. change allow write specific S3 Methods extend capabilities package. as_cff.Bibtex(). as_cff.bibentry(), replacing cff_parse_citation(). as_cff.person(), similar as_cff_person() person objects. recommend using as_cff_person() since can coerce also string representing authors BibTeX markup ("{von Neumen}, James"), can’t captured properly via methods. New as_bibentry() method variety classes (character, list, NULL classes defined cffr). New as_cff_person() method. .data.frame.cff(). .person(), although definitions.person definitions.entity (e.g. authors, contacts, editors, publisher, etc.). head.cff(), tail.cff(). toBibtex.cff().

title: cffr 1.0.0
text: API completely reviewed provide clarity functions naming facilitate internal maintenance. change affects non-core functions. Now function less things better. old API deprecated warn used, providing advice replacement function.

title: cffr 1.0.0
text: cff_to_bibtex() cff_extract_to_bibtex(): replaced as_bibentry() S3 generic. cff_parse_person() cff_parse_person_bibtex(): replaced as_cff_person() S3 generic. cff_parse_citation(): replaced as_cff() S3 generic. cff_from_bibtex(): replaced cff_read_bib() (*.bib files) cff_read_bib_text() (character strings). write_bib() write_citation() : replaced cff_write_bib() cff_write_citation() respectively. Argument path cff() also deprecated, use cff_read() instead.

title: cffr 1.0.0
text: cff_read_cff_citation(), cff_read_description(), cff_read_citation() cff_read_bib(). New cff_modify() function updating modifying cff objects easily.

title: cffr 1.0.0
text: Minimum R version required now 4.0.0. @inbook @book gains new value CFF series provided: collection-type: book-series. Can handle BibLaTeX @inbook, differs significantly BibTeX @inbook.

Now (invisible) result cff_validate() includes summary errors () attributes() named "error", jsonvalidate::json_validate() verbose = TRUE: verbose? TRUE, attribute "errors" list validation failures data.frame Improvements extraction `date-release`.

title: cffr 0.0.2
text: cffr part now rOpenSci. Update docs README. Add fuzzy match keys parameter. New dataset: cran_to_spdx. Add DOI https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.5509766 Citation installed packages extracted using citation(). Auto-generating preferred-citation key DESCRIPTION. Rename cff_schema_definitions_reference() cff_schema_definitions_refs(). repository key supported. Added vignette: vignette("crosswalk", package = "cffr"). Add support Bioconductor packages. New function: cff_gha_update().
